. This bug is on every Mac yours and mine, and its as follows:
1) On Mac when you lunch Koala, it gets lunched with the environment containing a PATH = "/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin".
2) Node.js gets installed in /usr/local/bin/node.
3) Koala executes the lessc with the same environment.
4) lessc is a node.js program which starts be #!/usr/bin/env node
5) env can't find node
. I found a quick fix:
1) sudo nano /usr/local/bin/koala-lessc
2) write:
```
!/bin/sh
/usr/local/bin/node /usr/local/bin/lessc $@
```
3) sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/koala-lessc
4) use usr/local/bin/koala-lessc as compiler path in Koala
Hope it help
Cheers

After reviewing the code (it's been a long time since I worked on Koala), I saw that a compiler if only required to implement a single method compile(file, emitter).
 The file parameter is File object representing the file to compile
 The emitter parameter is an object with an emit method:
    * you should call emitter.emit('fail') if the file could not be compiled (additionally you can call this.throwError(errorMessage, filePath) to an error notification)
    * you should call emitter.emit('done') when the file has been compiled successfully
    * you should call emitter.emit('always') after the compiler has finished successfully or otherwise
The File object has, among other things (the full list here):
 name which is the base name of the file
 src which is the full path of the file
 output which is the full path of the output file
 settings which is the settings used to compile this file

fvsch:
I don't understand why tools such as Koala (including Prepros, LiveReload, and probably others) default to compiling files unless you uncheck them or exclude them or import them.
On the CSS side, a typical project has one main stylesheet (Less, Sass, etc.) importing a few or sometimes dozens of "partials" or "module stylesheets". When you default to compiling everything you can, you end up with lots of false positives, compilation errors, etc.
Maybe that's helpful for people new to preprocessors, but if you know what you're doing you don't want your tools making those kind of decisions automatically.
. That's a Less, problem, not a Koala problem.
Less cannot substract pixels from percentages, since it doesn't know how many pixels is "100%" or how much in percentage is "40px" (this is bound to be different depending on the viewport width in many cases, by the way).
You have two options:
1. Write your styles differently altogether (are you just trying to add 20px margins on each side of an element, for instance?).
2. Use the browser's built-in calc function, in which case you don't want Less to process calc(100% - 40px), you want it to output it as-is.
Browser support for calc: http://caniuse.com/#search=calc
Tell Less to ignore calc: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16323310/how-can-i-instruct-less-to-ignore-math-for-certain-styles (or use the Strict Math option)

SCSS files that contain UTF-8 characters require a @charset "UTF-8"; at the beginning of the file.

What's?

As there are several ways to define the character encoding of a style sheet, the browser will try the following methods in the following order (and stop as soon as one yields a result) :
    The value of the Unicode byte-order character placed at the beginning of the file.
    The value given by the charset attribute of the Content-Type: HTTP header or the equivalent in the protocol used to serve the style sheet.
    The @charset CSS at-rule.
    Use the character encoding defined by the referring document: the charset attribute of the  element. This method is obsoleted in HTML5 and must not be used.
    Assume that the document is UTF-8

- Adjust the following settings to your preference. Be sure to keep Auto compile checked.

. Hi AnaCamelo,
I can't say exactly why that problem has arisen, but you can try some few troubleshooting tips to get you much closer to the particular file or line that causes it.

There should be a file from where you include all the other LESS files, right? Comment out all but one of your LESS includes in that file and then compile.
For each LESS file that compiles successfully without errors, uncomment another file and compile.
Keep uncommenting and compiling until you will get to a file that will cause the errors.
Once you pinpoint the particular file spewing those errors, Proceed to comment our huge blocks of code within that file and uncomment block by block as you compile.
You will eventually get down to the block or line of code that is causing the problem.

DenisCherniatev:
I my case the problem was in non ASCII chars in my USER_HOME folder. Because Koala stores it's cache, logs and settings in USER_HOME/.koala.
I've solved the problem this way:
1. Shut down the Koala. Move USER_HOME/.koala to C:/Users/Default/docker/.koala
use any path that is free of non ASCII chars.
2. in file C:\Program Files (x86)\Koala\app\scripts\FileManager.js
replace:
exports.userDataDir  = path.join(process.env[(process.platform === 'win32') ? 'USERPROFILE' : 'HOME'], (process.platform === 'darwin') ? 'Library/Application Support/Koala/UserData' :'.koala');
with:
exports.userDataDir  = 'C:/Users/Default/docker/.koala';
3. in file C:\Program Files (x86)\Koala\app\scripts\pages\log.js
replace:
var errorLog = process.env[(process.platform == 'win32') ? 'USERPROFILE' : 'HOME'] + '/.koala/error.log';
with:
var errorLog = 'C:/Users/Default/docker/.koala/error.log';
That's it. Do not forget save you changes.

// ### Other compile options, use the full name of options.
// e.g, ["--scss", ... ,"--no-cache"].
// Run the command 'sass -h' to see more options.
"customOptions": [
    "--precision 6 input.scss output.css"
],
